description: This Filipino garlic fried rice recipe is a clever way to use leftover white rice.
ingredient: [{"name": "cooked long grain white rice", "units": "cups", "amount": "3 to 4"}, {"name": "salt", "units": "teaspoon", "amount": "1"}, {"name": "vegetable oil", "units": "tablespoons", "amount": "2"}, {"name": "garlic", "units": "large cloves", "amount": "4"}, {"name": "white pepper", "units": "teaspoon", "amount": "1/4"}, {"name": "green onion or chives", "units": "thinly sliced", "amount": "1"}]
step_by_step: ["Add the cooked, cold rice to a large mixing bowl. Use your hands to fluff the grains to break apart and loosen them up.", "Sprinkle 1/2 teaspoon salt all over the rice. Mix well with a spoon and set aside.", "Place a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat and add the oil. Once hot, add the garlic and cook for 30 seconds to 1 minute until crisp and light golden brown but not burnt.", "Add the rice. Using a spatula or cooking spoon, stir thoroughly to mix the garlic and oil into the grains. This should take about 2 minutes.", "Lower the heat to medium if the skillet gets too hot. Sprinkle the remaining 1/2 teaspoon of salt and the white pepper all over the rice.", "Stir the rice well for seasonings to blend, about 1 to 2 minutes.", "Garnish with green onion or chives, if desired. Serve warm as an accompaniment to breakfast, lunch, or dinner."]
notes: If you're using leftover rice that was seasoned with salt, reduce the salt in the recipe accordingly. Keep leftover garlic fried rice in a covered container, refrigerated. It will last for up to 2 days.
